3 mindset shifts as you get into a P&L Leader Role: The P&L Leader role (the CEO of your business/vertical) is an Operating Role where you are responsible for the Delivery of Tangible and Comprehensive Targets around profitability, cashflow, volumes, etc. However, it is also a role where you need to Identify & Drive Strategic Priorities to transform the business. The Corner Office role is more about operating in the Unknown-Unknown Zone unlike most of the roles one may have done in the run up to this role where you are generally working in the Known-Known or Known-Unknown Zone. There are 3 mindset shifts that I have found to be helpful as you get into the role: 1. Create a "Mental Safe Zone" for yourself on the Operating Results. The temptation to jump right in when there is a mini crisis or shortfall in operating targets is very high, and before you know, it consumes most of your time and bandwidth (as you can always make that little extra impact with your involvement!). You need to Resist this Temptation and guide the team but not jump in to participate most of the time. You need to create a Safe Zone for yourself where you don't panic and jump into the action 2. Build your External Network. While you are very familiar and comfortable with the interactions within your team (given you are the boss, they will of course give you all the "right" messages & feedback!!), you need to build a diverse external network (external to your team) to get a sense of what's happening in the broader company/industry/economy. While everyone is focused on the internal action, you need to keep an eye on things happening around you 3. Create "New Dots". While people put a lot of focus on 'connecting the dots', I feel you first need to ensure you Create New Dots - how these connect to each other in times to come you may not even realize. Serendipity is very powerful and you need to increase your chances of such serendipitous gains by ensuring you create enough new dots Try to focus on these 3 and create enough time for yourself by doing 1 to be able to spend on points 2 & 3!! #ceoinsights #campustalks #careerwars #careerdevelopment #leadership #leadershipdevelopment #CreatingDots #mentorship

I had one of the most emotional days at work yesterday - I almost teared up. Not because I failed to deliver my work or faced pressure or stress. It was about leadership. Throughout my career, feedback was always focused on my work, helping me deliver good results for various organizations. However, when it came to managing people, I often received advice to be stricter and put more pressure on my team. Surprisingly, I have also had comments like I support and trust my team too much. Every time I heard such things, I would lose my confidence as a person leading and managing people. However, I still stayed true to my beliefs and observations about creating a safe, secure, and trustworthy environment for my team. Rarely have I come across people who would agree with the way I operate as a manager. Yesterday, for the first time in the last 8.5 years, I felt proud of the way I operated and managed my team. I realized that it is right to create a safe, secure, and trustworthy environment for my team. And that I was right when I thought about empowering and upskilling individuals instead of just assigning tasks. I'm proud of the way I operate and how it has allowed my team to thrive. Iâ€™d like to express my heartfelt gratitude to Robin and Jagadeesh for their invaluable insights during the leadership training workshop at Kovai.co in the last two days. To my fellow leaders and those on the path of managing teams: Trust yourself, embrace your unique approach, and, above all, lead with authenticity. Most importantly accept that everybody is different in their approach. It took me 8.5 years, but yesterday, I felt the pride of staying true to my values. Here's to many more years of fostering trust, empowerment, and success together as a team! #leadership #teambuilding

When you can help the new joiners to cross the dreadful waters in the initial days, results will follow. Every single person who joins a new company joins with expectations along with a lot of confusion. Expecting them to deliver on the very first day is unrealistic. The results wonâ€™t start changing drastically as soon as someone joins; you have to accept that thatâ€™s not how it works. You need to give them that time and bandwidth to understand your culture, to get along with your team, to get along with you, and to feel comfortable; all of this takes some time So, as a manager/recruiter/leader, be patient with them, carry them along initially, and run with them if you have to, but become a go-to person for them. Rather than being that person who hires and forgets, be that person who can make people feel that you can change their lives. This is how you onboard - with the patience to teach, run, and help them grow along with you.
